Graphical abstract Although CO and CO2 hydrogenation reactions have been extensively studied, there is still significant controversy regarding the mechanism of methane formation and the routes for byproducts, especially when both carbon sources are simultaneously present. This work combines kinetic, operando-spectroscopic, isotopic techniques and DFT calculations to elucidate the relationships between CO and CO2 hydrogenation over mono Ni, Co and bimetallic NiCo catalysts with similar metal dispersion. The bimetallic catalysts showed a slight synergistic effect for methane formation from CO, while from CO2 the effect was opposite, showing a negative shift of activity as compared with those observed on the monometallic catalysts. The kinetic analysis shows similar apparent order with respect to H2 (∼0.5) and an inverse secondary isotope kinetic effect (<1) for both methanation reactions, suggesting that CH4 formation proceeds via C-O bond breaking in an H*-assisted mechanism, where the rate-determining step was not shown to be sensitive to the carbon source. The anti-synergistic effect observed on the bimetallic catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation is explained by the formation of unreactive HCOO* species (spectator), which generate a lower density of methane intermediates. On the other hand, the formation of the undesired products, i.e., CO or CO2 during CO2 or CO hydrogenation, respectively, shows relevant differences since the CO formation during CO2 hydrogenation proceeds through the desorption of the carbonyl species adsorbed on weak sites, meanwhile the CO2 formation from CO hydrogenation is due to a minority route of direct dissociation of CO, allowing the rejection of O* with CO* to produce CO2. This study contributes to elucidate the routes that determine the selectivity and reactivity for CO and CO2 hydrogenation and their mechanistic relationship. This information is valuable for the rational design and development of new materials with high performance during hydrogenation processes. Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 emissions are the main contributor to the increase in anthropogenic greenhouse gas concentration in the atmosphere, causing global warming and its associated problems [1]. One way to mitigate the environmental problems related to this molecule is through CO2 hydrogenation processes [2,3]. Specifically, such processes would facilitate the energy transition from an economy based on fossil fuels to one based on renewable energies [4]. More precisely, this would be achieved by integrating hydrogen produced via water electrolysis, generating greater stability to renewable energies. Usually, the hydrogenation processes of CO and CO2 to methane have been studied separately [5–9]. In practice, both carbon oxides are related to each other through a network of reactions, given by equations (1)–(3). Moreover, the kinetic relevance of the presence of one carbon oxide on the hydrogenation of the other has been already demonstrated on a Ru/Al2O3 catalyst [10]. (1) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O (2) CO + 3 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + H 2 O (3) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ C O + H 2 O Nevertheless, several mechanistic studies continue to show persistent controversies about such reactions. In this sense, different routes for the hydrogenation of both carbon oxides have been proposed. Mainly, these mechanisms have been divided in (i) direct or (ii) assisted COx dissociation pathways. On the one hand, it has been suggested that CO2 would be activated by a hydrogen-assisted route through formate species [11–13]. This route would be inhibited by the strong adsorption of CO [10], during the simultaneous hydrogenation of both CO and CO2. On the other hand, during the hydrogenation of CO, the carbonyl species are formed directly and are preferentially hydrogenated to methane [10]. Other authors agree on a similar mechanism for both hydrogenations, where the only difference is the carbon source, coming rather from CO2 or CO [8,14,15], which means that the reaction follows an identical pathway after generation of the carbonyl species. In these cases, it is claimed that the differences in CO and CO2 hydrogenation activity are not due to a change in the reaction mechanism but by a difference in the coverage of carbonyl species (CO*) which is larger for CO hydrogenation and results in a lower activity as the CO2 and H2 activation sites are inhibited [8]. Therefore, CO* species would be considered a key reaction intermediate in both hydrogenation processes, where the reaction would proceed by H*-assisted dissociation of CO* (i.e. formation of *HCOH*)[15]. In this way, during CO2 hydrogenation, there would be a prior direct dissociation of CO2 to CO* and O* in an equilibrated step as proposed on Ru/SiO2 [15], Rh/SiO2 [8], Ni/SiO2, Co/SiO2 and NiCo/SiO2 in our previous work [16]. On the other hand, DFT and microkinetics calculations on Ni surfaces have proposed that the formation of CH4 would proceed mainly through the formate pathway (H-assisted dissociation of CO2) and via carbide (direct dissociation of CO2 and subsequent assisted or direct CO dissociation depending on the surface)[17]. Thus direct dissociation of CO* that has been proposed over Ni/SiO2 [18] and Co [19] contradicts studies that indicate that the dissociation of diatomic molecules with strong bonds, such as CO, would take place through a bimolecular route [20,21]. In fact, the high barriers observed for the direct dissociation of CO* on different surfaces are due to a high bond dissociation energy (BDE) of CO (1070 kJ mol−1 25 °C in the gas phase [22]). Thus, direct dissociation would require low-coordination surface sites [21]. Even though the dissociation of the first C-O bond of CO2 shows a lower BDE (526 kJ mol−1 25 °C in the gas phase [22]), the routes of H*-assisted CO2 dissociation through the formation of formate species have been proposed over various types of catalysts such as Ru/Al2O3 [10,23], Pd/Al2O3 [12,13], and even Ni/SiO2 [24] catalysts. Evidently, the sequence of elementary steps during CO and CO2 hydrogenation remains controversial, persisting in the different mechanisms and, in some cases, not allowing the mechanistic connections between them. Thus, a comprehensive and systematic study for the simultaneous hydrogenation of CO and CO2 is needed to unravel the mechanistic interrelationships between both reactions. In addition, the development of mechanistic studies on bimetallic catalysts has been useful to explain the geometric or ligand effects. Particularly, this allows to obtain information about the nature and participation of the active sites [25,26]. On the other hand, it should be considered that the formation of by-products takes place both during the CO2 and CO hydrogenation processes. For the former, the formation of CO(g) is related to the weak adsorption of the carbonyl species, as shown in our previous work over Ni, Co and NiCo [16]. Similar performance has been observed on NiPd [27] or Ni catalysts where it shows the accumulation of carbonaceous species in contrast to clean Ni surfaces, which additionally evidenced a higher selectivity to CH4 [28]. In all the previously mentioned catalysts, the weakly adsorbed species would be responsible for the formation of CO(g), while the multi-bonded carbonyls would be the key intermediates for methane formation. On the other side, for the CO hydrogenation, CO2 production is evidenced. The formation of this molecule, on Fe-based catalysts, would be ascribed to the oxygen rejection pathway produced during direct CO dissociation [9,29]. This O* must be removed through the formation of CO2 or H2O, with rejection via CO2 dominating, due to the high coverage of the carbonyl species. On the other hand, the H-assisted CO dissociation pathways would not allow the formation of the O* species, forming OH*, which allows the rejection of oxygen through H2O during the catalytic cycle, as proposed on Co/SiO2 and Ru/SiO2 under Fischer-Tropsch (FTS) conditions [29–31]. Here we provide a thorough kinetic, isotopic and spectroscopic analysis to explain the mechanistic interplay between CO and CO2 hydrogenations over Ni, Co and bimetallic NiCo catalysts. With the obtained information, the mechanistic controversies that determine the catalytic performance are unraveled. In addition, a SSITKA-DRIFTS/MS 13CO2/12CO2 study was carried out, which allows to unequivocally understand the kinetic differences between CO and CO2 hydrogenation reactions, as well as the obstacles for the CO2 hydrogenation. Thus, this study contributes to the understanding of the requirements and the nature of the sites involved in the CO2 and CO hydrogenation reaction. The obtained results allow the use of information obtained in both processes to facilitate their implementation, and take advantage of the knowledge of both reactions, allowing the design of new catalysts in a rational way. 2 Methods 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts NixCo(1-x) mono- and bimetallic catalysts supported on SiO2 were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method as detailed described elsewhere [17]. SiO2 (Saint Gobain Nor-Pro, 180–350 µm, 230 m2 g−1) was used as support for bimetallic and monometallic Ni catalysts. Different aqueous solutions of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck 99.999 % purity) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Merck 99.999 % purity) were prepared in order to synthesize catalysts with different Co/(Co + Ni) compositions. The monometallic Co/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the same method over SiO2 (Alfa Aesar, 150–380 µm, 100 m2 g−1). The impregnated materials were dried overnight at 105 °C. Subsequently, the samples were reduced in a flow of 40 mL· min−1 of H2 at 400 °C for the Ni catalyst and 500 °C for the bimetallic and monometallic Co catalysts. The reduction was carried out for 2 h with a heating ramp of 1 °C·min−1 for Co and 2 °C·min−1 for bimetallic and monometallic Ni catalysts. The materials were characterized by XRD and TEM techniques, and the results are presented in a previous work [16]. By means of these techniques, the Ni, Co and NiCo bimetallic crystal size, mean particle size and dispersion index were determined. Additionally, through HR-TEM-EDS and CO-induced segregation techniques at the Operando-FTIR setup, the formation of the bimetallic phase was demonstrated in the representative Ni0.5Co0.5/SiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, the mass composition of the catalysts was quantified by inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS). 2.2 Rate and selectivity measurements CO and CO2 hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a fixed-bed stainless steel tubular reactor (3/4″ o.d.) under differential reactor condition. A catalyst mass ranging from 20 to 40 mg (particle size 106–380 µm), contained between two quartz wool bed, was loaded. The bed temperature was controlled and monitored using a K-type thermocouple in contact with the outside of the catalyst bed. The catalysts were in situ reduced in hydrogen (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) following the corresponding thermal reduction programs described in section 2.1 with an H2 flow rate of 50 mL min−1. Subsequently, the catalysts were cooled down to the reaction temperatures. CH4, CO and CO2 formation rates were measured at temperatures between 250 and 330 °C by feeding 1–2 kPa of CO2 (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) and/or CO (10.23 % CO/He) and 10–25 kPa H2 (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity). N2 (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) was employed to balance the flows. A Perkin Elmer 8700 gas chromatograph was utilized to measure the concentration of CO2, CO, and CH4 in the outlet stream of the reactor. The gas chromatograph was equipped with a Porapak Q column and a FID coupled to a methanizer. Transport limitations were ruled out using Weisz-Prater and Mears criteria (Section S1 in Supplementary information). Reaction rate measurements for both CO and CO2 hydrogenation were carried out until steady state operation was ensured. The last 3 points of each steady state condition was used to obtain the reaction rates. Representative figures of time-on-stream profile for CO, CO2 and CH4 turnover rates have been added to de Supplementary Material (Figure S3.10 and S3.11). Kinetic isotopic studies were performed on monometallic and representative bimetallic Ni0.5Co0.5/SiO2 catalysts for CO and CO2 hydrogenation in a similar reaction system. The experiments were conducted using a mixture of 25 kPa of H2 (or D2), 1 kPa of CO or CO2, and N2 as balance, with a total flow rate of 100 mL·min−1. The outlet effluents were measured using an AutosystemXL gas chromatograph. The gas chromatograph was equipped with a packed column (Carboxen 1000) and TCD and FID detectors preceded by a methanizer. The kinetic isotopic effect (KIE) for the distinct products was calculated as KIE=ri,H/ri,D, with ri,H and ri,D being the formation rates of CO, CO2 and CH4 under H2 and D2, respectively. 2.3 Operando-FTIR measurements Operando FTIR spectra were measured on a Thermo Nicolet is-10 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a high temperature reaction cell (CaF2 windows, In Situ Research & Instruments). Likewise, simultaneous CO and CO2 hydrogenation measurements were performed on a high temperature reaction cell with KBr windows (Harrick Scientific) according to the procedure previously described [5,16].The self-supported catalyst wafers in the IR cell were reduced in-situ under a flow rate of 30 mL· min−1 H2 (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) at 350 °C for 2 h following the heating ramp of section 2.1. The spectra were recorded with 4 cm−1 resolution and 32 scans per spectrum, in a wavenumber range between 3500 and 1200 cm−1. The total feed flow during the measurements was 60 mL·min−1, with 10 % Ar as internal standard. Measurements under reaction conditions were carried out at partial pressures of CO (10.23 % CO/He) or CO2 (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) between 1–2 kPa, H2 (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) 10–40 kPa, Ar (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity) as internal standard and balance of He (Air Liquide, 99.999 % purity). The gases were fed at the reaction temperature until steady state was reached using mass flow controllers (Kofloc 8500, Kojima Instruments), whereas transient studies were carried out by an abrupt switch of the feed through a four-way valve. The effluent gases were analyzed by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar GSD 320, Pfeiffer). The evolution of the signals m/z = 44 (CO2), 40 (Ar), 28 (CO), 18 (H2O), 15 (CH4), 2 (H2) was registered at a frequency of 1 s−1. Measurements of the simultaneous CO and CO2 hydrogenation reactions were performed in the high temperature reaction cell (KBr windows, Harrick Scientific). The partial pressure of CO was varied between 0 and 1 kPa while keeping constant the pressure of 1 kPa of CO2 and 25 kPa of H2 (He balance). In addition, CO hydrogenation measurements were also performed by feeding 1 kPa CO, 25 kPa H2 and He as balance. The same procedure was followed for the reduction of the catalyst wafers. In this case, the data was saved with 10 scans per spectrum. The evolution of the different signals in the effluent was followed using the same quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar GSD 320, Pffeiffer). Simultaneous 13CO-12CO2-H2 measurements were carried out in a reaction cell (KBr windows, Harrick Scientific), where different concentrations of 12CO2-13CO-H2-balance He were fed, at a total flow rate of 100 mL·min−1, with 5 mL·min−1 Ar as internal standard. The gases were measured and quantified using the internal standard method [32]. Previously, the contribution of the products in the different signals were quantified and, from it, it was subtracted from the measured signals in order to avoid interfering with the product measurements. 2.4 SSITKA-DRIFTS measurements 13CO2/12CO2 Steady-state transient kinetic analysis coupled with operando-DRIFTS (SSITKA-DRIFTS) were performed in a stainless-steel low dead-volume cell (Harrick Scientific) with ZnSe windows. He (99.999 %, Air Liquide), Ar (99.999 %, Air Liquide), H2 (99.999 %, Air Liquide), 12CO2 (99.999 %, AirGas) and 13CO2 (99.99 %, Linde, >99 % isotopic purity) were employed. The gas mixture of Ar/12CO2/H2 was feed to the DRIFTS cell through a 4-way valve, which allowed the quick switch to a Ar/He(tracer)/13CO2/H2 mixture after reaching steady state. The study was carried out at a constant pressure of 1 bar (abs) with a H2/CO2 = 4:1 and 250 °C. Furthermore, the effluent gases were monitored with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar GSD 320, Pffeiffer) and saved at a frequency of 1 s−1. The evolution of the signals m/z = 44 (CO2), 40 (Ar), 28 (CO), 18 (H2O), 15 (CH4), 2 (H2), 17(13CH4), 29 (13CO) was followed. Experiments were performed at different spatial velocities, varying the total flow rate from 15 mL·min−1 to 40 mL·min−1, while keeping constant the partial pressures of reactants to eliminate readsorption effects. Furthermore, every measurement was corrected by the gas-phase hold up and chromatographic effect, as described in the literature [33,34]. From the MS and FTIR results, the residence time of intermediates, the number of intermediates and the intrinsic turnover frequency for each product were estimated according to the following expressions, respectively. (4) τ i = ∫ 0 t s s F i t - F C O 2 t d t (5) N i = τ i r i (6) TO F Pi ITK = k i = 1 / τ i 0 Here, F i , r i and τ i 0 correspond to the normalized MS or FTIR signal of species i, the steady-state formation rate under SSITKA conditions and the residence time of intermediates extrapolated to infinite flow. 2.5 DFT calculations Electronic properties and key adsorption and reactive steps were studied using density functional theory. Model Ni, Co and NiCo (111) and (100) surfaces were constructed from a 3.55 Å DFT-optimized fcc bulk lattice parameters, close to experimental values. Surface models included four layers with 16 atoms each and a 15 Å vacuum, only the top two layers and adsorbed species were allowed to relax until all forces were below 0.02 eV/Å. The VASP 5.4 DFT code [35–38] with RPBE [39] functional were used to properly represent CO adsorption strength trends [40]. The Projector Augmented Wave method [41,42] was used for core interactions and cutoff energy was set to 460 eV for the spin-polarized calculations. A 0.05 Methfessel-Paxton [43] smearing (then extrapolated to 0 K) was used to accelerate electronic convergence to < 10-6 eV difference between iterations. All surfaces employed a 4x4x1 Monkhorst-Pack mesh [44] while isolated species were placed in 15 Å boxes and computed using a single k-point. Adsorption energies are computed as Eads = Esup-A – Esup – EA, the difference between the adsorbed model energy (Esup-A) and energies of the clean surface (Esup) and isolated adsorbate (EA). CO energetics were properly described by RPBE but a + 0.3721 eV correction was fitted for the electronic energy of CO2, similar corrections have been previously used [17,45,46] and do not affect discussed trends. Vibrational frequencies are computed for adsorbed species leading to estimate of the Gibbs free energies [47]. Transition state search employed the Climbing-Image nudged elastic band method [48], then refined by the dimmer method [49] and confirmed through frequency calculations. Comparing initial energies (GI) with activated (GTS) and final states (GF) provides activation barriers (ΔGA=GTS-GI) and reaction energies (ΔGrx = GF-GI), respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition and structural properties of the synthesized catalyst In a previous work [16], the Ni, Co, and NiCo silica-supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts were characterized by several techniques (XRD, TEM, ICP-MS); some of these results are also shown in the Supplementary Material (Figure S8.1). The results are summarized in Table 1 and show that the catalysts have a similar mean particle size. Likewise, the dispersion index lower than 1.5 indicates a narrow particle size distribution [50]. These measurements rule out the possible effects of structure sensitivity on the catalytic performance, which have been previously evidenced for CO2 and CO hydrogenations [14,51–54]. Furthermore, the formation of the bimetallic NiCo alloy was demonstrated by HR-TEM-EDS and CO-induced segregation techniques performed at the Operando-FTIR setup [16]. In fact, TEM characterization coupled to EDX for the representative Ni0.5Co0.5/SiO2 bimetallic catalyst show the homogeneous distribution of the Ni and Co elements in the bulk metallic phase (Figure S8.1b). Moreover, the formation of the bimetallic phase is demonstrated through XRD results, where the position of the peaks associated with the bimetallic phases appears between the Ni (44.4°) and Co (44.2°) monometallic signals, shifting towards smaller angles as the Co content increases (Figure S8.1 a); this reaffirms the homogeneity of the bimetallic nanoparticles [55]. 3.2 Effect of catalyst composition on turnover rates and selectivity For the CO2 hydrogenation, the rate of CH4 formation (TOFCH4) was higher for the monometallic catalysts (Ni/SiO2 and Co/SiO2) than for the bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 1 a). This phenomenon exhibits itself as a negative shift with respect to the average-weighted activity value of the monometallic samples (i.e. an anti-synergistic effect for the CH4 formation). On the contrary, for the CO hydrogenation, a slight synergistic effect was observed for the bimetallic catalysts with respect to the average-weighted activity of the monometallic samples (Fig. 1a), although the methane activity asymptotically approaches the Co/SiO2 activity as the cobalt content increases (note that at Co concentrations above 0.5 there would be no substantial change in activity compared to Co/SiO2). This suggests that the NixCo(1-x) alloys possess electronic or configurational characteristics, necessary for CH4 formation, that more closely resemble Co than Ni during CO hydrogenation as has been observed electronically through theoretical results (Section S2 in Supporting information). The phenomenon observed under CO and CO2 hydrogenation was again evidenced under other reaction conditions (temperature and reactant partial pressures, Section S3 in Supporting Information). Fig. 1a also shows that the rate of CH4 formation on Ni/SiO2 monometallic catalyst was higher for CO2 hydrogenation than for CO hydrogenation at every studied conditions. A similar behavior has been reported for Rh/SiO2 catalysts [8] and was attributed to a higher coverage of the CO* species on the surface during CO hydrogenation. Nevertheless, this coverage effect cannot explain the higher CH4 formation rate observed for CO hydrogenation over bimetallic catalysts as compared with the monometallic materials. On the other hand, the Co/SiO2 catalyst shows no significant difference in activity regardless the carbon source (Fig. 1a). The formation of CO or CO2, generated during CO2 or CO hydrogenation, respectively, shows a different behavior as a function of Co content (Fig. 1b). The CO formation rate increases with Co loading while the CO2 formation rate practically does not change with Co content in the catalyst, consequently the difference between both formation rates increases with the Co content. It is also observed that the CO formation rates during the CO2 hydrogenation resulted between 6 and 24 times higher than the CO2 formation rate from CO hydrogenation. This significantly lower CO2 formation from CO hydrogenation has also been previously evidenced on Ni, Co and Fe-based catalysts [9,29,56–58] and it is explained by the difficulty of forming O* species from the high-demanding-energy direct (unassisted) C≡O bond dissociation [22], following their removal by CO* through the CO2 formation on CO* dominated surfaces. For this reason, it has been proposed two parallel mechanism for CO hydrogenation with the H*-assisted dissociation as the preferential route for CO hydrogenation on Co [9,29,57], Ru [15] and Rh [8] catalysts, showing lower energy barriers and allowing oxygen rejection mainly through H2O. On the other hand, in the minor unassisted C≡O bond dissociation, O* can be removed either as CO2 (by CO*) or as H2O (by H*). Thus, the very low CO2 formation rate observed on the studied catalysts confirms that the methane formation through the hydrogenation of the remaining C* species is a minor pathway, especially on a surface dominated by CO* species. In summary, the studied catalysts show significantly higher rates for the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) than for the water gas shift (WGS). In this sense, the selectivity towards CH4 formation is dependent on both the nature of the active phase and the carbon source, as shown in Fig. 1c. The apparent activation energies for methane formation, Fig. 2 a, are in agreement with what has been observed in the literature on Ni catalysts (i.e. Eapp CO=96.7–116 kJ mol−1 [59] vs Eapp CO2 = 85–80 kJ mol−1 [28,6027]). A relationship is evidenced between the exhibited trends and the previously described synergistic and anti-synergistic effects during CO and CO2 hydrogenation, respectively. The Ni/SiO2 catalyst showed a lower activation energy during CO2 hydrogenation than during CO hydrogenation. This effect has been explained on Rh/SiO2 catalysts due to the higher coverage of the carbonyl species during CO hydrogenation [8]. In contrast, the bimetallic and the Co monometallic catalysts showed slightly lower apparent activation energies under CO hydrogenation than during CO2 hydrogenation. Furthermore, as for the methane formation turnover frequency, an asymptotic behavior on the activation energy with increasing Co content can be evidenced. This shows that there would be a closer energetic similarity between the bimetallic catalysts and the Co monometallic catalyst than with pure Ni catalyst. On the other hand, the effect of coverage, argued in Rh/SiO2 [8] and Ni/SiO2 [16] catalysts, cannot explain the lower apparent activation energy observed on Co-containing catalysts under CO hydrogenation as compared with CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 2a). The higher activation energy during CO2 hydrogenation in bimetallic samples could be explained by changes in the electronic configuration of Co or Ni. In these catalysts, it has been found changes in their d-bands and filling distribution, where the global effect of the Ni-Co interaction is a reduction of the band centers d for Co and Ni atoms in the NiCo (111) and, (100) surfaces [61]. Similarly, it has been shown, in NiPd catalysts, that a lower energy band d, in that case of Pd than Ni, generates a decrease in its reactivity during CO2 hydrogenation [27]. DFT calculations suggest that on NiCo surfaces Ni atoms gain electronic density and redistribute bands in similar proportion for the spin-up and spin-down components leading to a greater decrease of their d-bands, compared to Co that may become more relevant for the chemical reactivity of the surface (Section S2 in Supporting Information). This may suggest a greater effect on the electronic structure of Ni atoms and could explain the different catalytic behavior of the alloy, more similar to the Co catalyst under CO hydrogenation. In this regard, CO2 adsorption barriers on Ni, Co and NiCo (111) and (100) surfaces were studied. It was evidenced that there are no large differences in the adsorption energies when varying the active elements (<5 kJ·mol−1) suggesting that the CO2 adsorption is not a relevant factor in differentiating the reaction kinetics (Section S2 in Supporting Information). Thereafter, the activation energy of the dissociative adsorption of CO2 on the different surfaces was analyzed. It was observed that the Ni (111) and Ni (100) surfaces showed considerable differences in activation energies, being less active the (111) surfaces than the (100) (Section S2 in Supporting Information), in agreement with the literature [17,62]. On the other hand, the Co-based catalysts show a similar activation barrier between the different surfaces, consistent with the similar behavior among the Co-containing catalysts and their higher activity compared to Ni for CO2 activation. This explains the higher CO(g) formation observed experimentally and thus higher CO* coverages on available active sites. It should be considered that the available number of active sites may decrease with the concentration of spectator species, as demonstrated in the following sections. Fig. 2 b shows an evident linear trend with Co content in the apparent activation energies for CO and CO2 formation, showing a behavior different from that evidenced from the activation energies of CH4 formation. Thus, the differences in activation energies between the formation of methane and carbon oxides, and the different behavior of the turnover frequencies as the Co content varies rather suggests that different types of active site and/or different rate-determining step (RDS) are involved in the routes for CH4 and COx formation. In fact, it has been recently suggested that different types of sites play a role in the processes of CO2 and CO hydrogenation [15], but their nature and mechanism remain unclear. It should be taken into consideration that the differences in apparent activation energies observed as a function of catalysts composition could be caused not only by the differences in the energies involved in the rate and equilibrium constants of the rate determining step but also by the possible differences in surface coverage at the tested reaction conditions. 3.3 Effect of the partial pressure of reactants 3.3.1 CH4 formation rate Fig. 3 shows the H2 apparent orders of reaction for CH4 formation. Reaction orders close to 0.5 are observed, independently of the reactant (CO or CO2) and Co content. This suggests that at least 1 hydrogen atom is involved in the rate determining step of the methane formation. Therefore, the RDS could correspond to the H*-assisted dissociation of the strong C-O bond of the carbonyl species (CO*), as has been suggested for CO2 hydrogenation [24,17,11,13]. Furthermore, the negligible difference between the apparent orders with respect to PH2 suggests an identical participation of hydrogen in the rate-determining step for methane formation over both hydrogenations (i.e. CO2 and CO) on all studied catalysts. The observed values are in line with those reported for monometallic catalysts in the literature, between 0.4 and 0.6 for CO2 hydrogenation [57] and between 0.6 and 0.8 for CO hydrogenation [59,63]. On the other hand, the apparent reaction orders for CH4 formation with respect to CO2 or CO (Fig. 3b) show significant differences when comparing the two reactants. In fact, the order with respect to CO2 is close to 0, independently of the Co content (i.e. between −0.09 and 0.03) and of the temperature, as its has been shown in a precedent work [16]. On the contrary, for the CO hydrogenation there is considerable variation in the reaction order with respect to the catalyst composition. More precisely, negative orders for monometallic and close to 0 and positive orders for bimetallic catalysts are evidenced. The negative order observed in the monometallic samples are in agreement with what was observed in Fig. 1, since a higher coverage of carbonaceous species (i.e. carbonyls) would generate a negative reaction dependence on CO. This behavior has been observed for Ni/SiO2 [24,51,64] Co/SiO2 [15,20,21], Ru/SiO2 [11,15] or Rh/SiO2 [8] catalysts during CO hydrogenation. Likewise, for the bimetallic catalyst, apparent orders of CH4 formation with respect to PCO are slightly higher (Fig. 3b, blue) than those obtained over monometallic catalysts. This would be explained by a lower coverage of carbonyl species in bimetallic surfaces than the monometallic surfaces due to a lower adsorption enthalpy of the CO species, caused by the electronic changes of the alloy as compared with monometallic catalysts according to the enthalpies obtained by DFT on these surfaces (Section S2 in Supporting Information). 3.3.2 CO or CO2 formation rates The apparent reaction orders for CO and CO2 formations during CO2 and CO hydrogenation, respectively, are presented in Fig. 4 . The order of CO formation on PH2 for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction is close to 0 for all catalysts, regardless the Co content. On the other hand, during CO hydrogenation the order of CO2 formation with respect to PH2 is slightly negative under the studied conditions. It should be noted that previous IR studies have shown that H2 pressure during CO2 hydrogenation has no effect on the coverage of most abundant surface species (CO*), indicating that the H* species should not be considered in the balance of sites as MARI. This effect has also been evidenced in Co [5] and Rh [6] catalysts during CO hydrogenation. Thus, the lower order on PH2 for CO hydrogenation could be due to the fact that CO2 formation requires a previous step of O* species formation, more probably through the direct dissociation of CO* on low coordination surfaces, which have shown lower direct dissociation barriers (Co 68–136 kJ·mol−1 at modest coverage < 0.5 ML CO* [21]). Then, these O* species can follow two routes, oxidize the CO* to form CO2 or are hydrogenated to form the hydroxyl species. Thus, lower order values would indicate that a fraction of the O* species is hydrogenated to hydroxyls, therefore generating a decrease in the apparent order of reaction with respect to H2 (Section 3.7 and Section S.4 in Supporting Information for more details on the derivation of the reaction mechanism). On the other hand, the apparent orders with respect to PCO2 for CO formation (Fig. 4b, red symbols) were found to be close to 0.5 and independent of Co content, while the apparent orders observed with respect to PCO to form CO2 (Fig. 4b, blue symbols) are lower and tend to decrease with Co content. It is noteworthy that kinetic descriptors shown above have been obtained at low and similar conversions for all catalysts in order to minimize possible effect of conversion previously reported on Ni [65] and Ru [15]. Thus, Figure S3.3 (Supplementary Material) shows an average CO2 conversion close to 12 % for measurements at 280 °C for all catalysts; since this is the highest temperature evaluated for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, lower conversions were obtained at the rest of reaction conditions. 3.4 Operando-FTIR-MS measurements during CO, CO2 and CO-CO2 hydrogenation In order to determine the species involved during the CO, CO2 and CO/CO2 mixture hydrogenations a series of in situ FTIR measurements were performed under steady state and transient conditions. The prevalence of direct CO2 dissociation mechanism over mono- and bimetallic catalysts was previously demonstrated (Fig. 5 a red dotted lines) [16]. In this case, the material was in-situ reduced in H2 followed by purging with He at high temperatures in order to avoid H* remnants on the surface and then exposed to a flow of pure CO2 at 200 °C. The growth of carbonyl species was evidenced, which demonstrate the existence of direct dissociation of CO2 over both Ni and the bimetallic catalysts. In addition, the spectra obtained during CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 5a) showed higher intensity in the peaks associated to bridge and multi-bonded carbonyl over the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, which have been previously related to the formation of methane [25,27,28]. More precisely, an interaction with CO dominated by 2π* back-donation has been observed over Ni-based catalysts, thereafter favoring bridge coordination [66]. On the other hand, the presence of H2 would increase the π -donation from Ni into an antibonding π -orbital of the CO, as has been observed on Rh [8,67], where there is an increase of multi-bonded carbonyl species in its presence It can be observed that during the direct dissociation of CO2 on a clean surface (without presence of H*) the bands of the carbonyl species are located at slightly higher wavenumbers when compared to the CO2 + H2 reaction condition. This was also evidenced on Ni catalyst during CO feeding without hydrogen and with hydrogen (Fig. 5b), where the strength of the carbonyl species at bridge and multi-bond sites is favored. On the other hand, the linear carbonyl species, associated with the formation of CO [16,28], does not show a significant shift, nor significant changes in their intensities and wavenumber in the presence of H2. This is consistent with the close-to-cero order on PH2 shown in Fig. 4a. Moreover, the tendency of CO to increase with cobalt content (Fig. 1b), as does the linear carbonyl/multi-bonded carbonyl ratio (Fig. 5a), reaffirms that linear species would have a greater influence on CO formation. On the other side, during CO hydrogenation, it can be observed that the behavior in terms of surface species is similar, evidencing mainly linear and multi-bonded carbonyl species. The remarkable difference is related to formate species, which were evidenced during CO2 hydrogenation, mainly on the bimetallic, but not present during CO hydrogenation. It should be noted that on SiO2 there is no formation of formates upon CO feeding [16], unlike what was observed for the case of ZrO2 when interacting with the hydroxyl groups present [68]. Therefore, the formation of the formates species would occur on the active element or at its metal-support interface, and its formation is only possible during CO2 hydrogenation on SiO2-supported catalysts, i.e. by an addition of hydrogen to CO2 which does not dissociate directly. The higher intensity observed in Co during CO hydrogenation, Fig. 5b, is due to the fact that the measurements on Ni/SiO2 and NiCo/SiO2 were performed in another reaction cell, so their comparison must be only qualitative. Fig. 6 shows the Operando-FTIR study of the hydrogenation of a CO/CO2 mixture over the representative Ni0.5Co0.5/SiO2 bimetallic catalyst. The CO2 partial pressure was kept constant while the CO pressure was varied (Run 2–3). In addition, the individual hydrogenations of CO2 (Run 1) and CO (Run 4) were also measured. Under CO2 hydrogenation conditions (Run 1), the formation of linear (∼2050 cm−1) and multi-bonded (1700–1950 cm−1) carbonyl species was observed, as well as bands associated with formate species (HCOO*, ∼1595 cm−1). Ni/SiO2 and Co/SiO2 catalysts, which are more active and selective to methane than bimetallic catalyst during CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. 1), did not exhibit formate species under the studied conditions (Fig. 5). When CO was added to a CO2-containing mixture (Run 2), an increase in the intensities of linear and multi-bonded carbonyl species was evidenced. In addition, a shift to higher wavenumbers of the carbonyl peaks was detected, which has been related to an increased dipole–dipole interaction between carbonyls at the surface [69,70,66]. At these conditions, an increase in the rate of CH4 formation was evidenced from MS signal. Despite this, formates reach a final intensity like that observed in the absence of CO, as observed from the comparison between Run 1 and Run 2. On the other hand, under the individual CO hydrogenation step (Run 4) no formate species were observed, which confirms that these species are only formed in the presence of CO2 on these catalysts and that their coverage depends directly on CO2 partial pressure. Furthermore, the higher methane concentrations are obtained for the hydrogenation in the presence of CO, as seen from runs 2, 3 and 4, which is consistent with what was observed from the measurement of the TOF over the bimetallic catalyst (Fig. 1a). Moreover, as the CO pressure increases, an increase in the intensity of the band of linear-CO is observed, while the trend of the multi-bonded carbonyl band appears to be asymptotic, as is the formation of CH4. It is thus concluded that the generation of formate is only dependent on the CO2 feed and that this species would not be involved in the formation of CH4. Following the procedure developed by Lin & Bhan (2023)[71] to determine the interplay between CO2 hydrogenation reactions, thermodynamic constraints were established for the reversible reactions involved in this study. The global reversibility calculated for methane formation from CO2 resulted to be approximately 8 orders of magnitude lower than the RWGS (Section S7 in Supporting information). This result suggests that it is not possible to rule out a consecutive pathway through the direct dissociation of CO2 to CO* which then hydrogenates to form methane, contrary to what was observed for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over Cu/Zn/Al2O3 catalysts, where this procedure allows to rule out such a consecutive reaction pathway [71]. Therefore, in order to get insight into the mechanistic relationship between both pathways, operando-FTIR with simultaneous feeding of 13CO, 12CO2 and H2 was performed. As expected, when 12CO2 and H2 were the only reactants, the solely formation of 12CH4 was evidenced (Fig. 7 a). Thereafter, the 12CH4 signal increased slightly when the partial pressure of 12CO2 raised from 0.15 to 0.2 kPa. Nonetheless, no subsequent change was observed when the partial pressure was increased to 0.5 kPa, which is consistent with the close-to-zero order on PCO2 observed for CH4 formation shown in Fig. 3b. Interesting, once 13CO is co-fed, and as its partial pressure increases, the formation of 12CH4 drops rapidly (Fig. 7a), while the 13CH4 increases from zero and stabilizes after ∼ 1.5 ks. In addition, Fig. 7b shows that 12CO formation rate increases with PCO2, which is consistent with the positive 0.5 apparent order shown in Fig. 4b. It is noteworthy that 12CO is also formed in the simultaneous presence of 13CO and 12CO2 in the feed. In fact, as the partial pressure of 13CO increases, there is a sudden rise in 12CO, followed by a subsequent decrease in its formation. This trend may be associated to the fact that 12CO possesses a higher zero-point energy than 13CO, being less stable and gradually replacing 12CO* with 13CO* as evidenced by the shift of the bands associated with carbonyl species towards lower wavenumbers, Fig. 7c. In this sense, since the wavenumber is inversely proportional to the root of the reduced masses, the expected value of the associated 13CO* species can be estimated (i.e.υ(13CO)/υ(12CO)=(μ12CO/μ13CO)0.5). This magnitude in the shift was experimentally corroborated for both carbonyl species upon feeding 13CO. Thus, the catalytic sites are being dominated by 13CO* in the presence of 13CO and 12CO2 in the feed, the latter is not allowed to dissociate, showing sustained decreases of both 12CO and 12CH4 during the reaction. Furthermore, the increase in 13CO2 formation with the partial pressure of 13CO evidenced in Fig. 7b (at 1.8–3 ks) is also coherent with the positive apparent order on PCO shown in Fig. 4b. It is thus evident that the hydrogenation reaction of CO2 or CO to methane is dominated by the hydrogenation of carbonyl species on sites of strong adsorption, while the formation of the by-products CO2 and CO are the result of the O* rejection upon reaction with the dominant CO* species or through desorption of weakly adsorbed carbonyl species, respectively. 3.5 H2-D2 kinetic isotope effect on CH4 and COx formation The H2-D2 kinetic isotope effect (KIE) under CO2 and CO hydrogenation conditions on mono- and bimetallic catalysts was studied. The overall kinetic isotope effects were calculated as the ratio between the formation rates measured with CO(or CO2)/H2/N2 and CO(or CO2)/D2/N2 mixtures. Fig. 8 shows the KIE values for CH4 formation from both CO and CO2 as a function of Co content. For both reactions it is observed that the methane formation rate is slightly higher with D2 than with H2, showing an inverse kinetic isotope effect (rH/rD<1). Likewise, a previous study for CO2 hydrogenation evidenced KIECH4 values close to 0.8 on Ni and Co monometallic catalysts and 0.9 on the bimetallic Ni0.5Co0.5 catalyst. These inverse kinetic isotope effects are in line with those reported for methane formation over Co/SiO2 [9,29,56] and supported Ni catalysts [72] during CO (between 0.63–0.79) and CO2 hydrogenation The similar H2-D2 overall kinetic isotope effect obtained for methane formation during both hydrogenations suggests that the same RDS operates for the formation of this product from both reactants. The almost constant KIE among both hydrogenations indicates that the coverage of kinetically relevant intermediates is not significantly affected by hydrogen pressure. It should be noted that the overall kinetic isotope effect also considers the contribution from the thermodynamic isotope effect (TIE). In this sense, by means of DFT-derived calculations on (111) and (100) Ni, Co and Ni0.5Co0.5 surfaces, the TIEs were calculated. Assuming a route of direct CO2 dissociation and subsequent assisted CO dissociation, it was possible to obtain isotopic kinetic effect values in agreement with those obtained experimentally during CO2 hydrogenation [16]. For the formation of the undesired products CO or CO2, an absence of kinetic isotope effects was evidenced, i.e., the replacement of H2 by D2 did not result in relevant changes in the formation of CO or CO2 (KIECO ≈ KIECO2 ≈ 1) from CO2 or CO hydrogenation, respectively. This confirms that the RDS in the formation pathway of the byproducts for both hydrogenations do not involve hydrogen in bond formation or bond cleavage. This also has been reported over Fe-based catalysts for CO hydrogenation and over Ni-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation [9,29,73]. Thus, the formation of CO during CO2 hydrogenation would proceed via a direct CO2 dissociation pathway, without H-assistance mechanism, (Fig. 5 and [16]), where the RDS would be the desorption of the weakly adsorbed carbonyl species, as previously stated on Ni, NiCo [16] and various Ni-based catalysts [28] and PtCo catalysts [74]. Also, the absence of hydrogen participation in the RDS for CO2 formation suggests that the O* formed during CO hydrogenation by the direct dissociation of CO are mainly rejected as CO2 upon reaction with the dominant CO* specie. The differences observed between the KIE values for methane (inverse KIECH4) and COx (no KIECOx) formation confirms that the reactions proceed with or without the H* participation in the RDS, respectively. These results are also consistent with the reaction orders on hydrogen pressure for methane (Fig. 3a) and COx (Fig. 4a) formations. Thus, kinetic and isotopic measurements suggest that the reaction mechanism for CH4 formation are similar for CO and CO2 hydrogenation. This suggests that the impact of the reagent on activity, evidenced in Fig. 1, could be related to the generation of spectator species, which do not interfere in the mechanism but occupy a fraction of the total sites. This has also been observed on Cu/Zn/Al2O3 catalysts for methanol synthesis [75]. 3.6 12CO2/13CO2 SSITKA-DRIFTS measurements The relationship between the different adsorbed species and the formation of CO, CO2 and CH4 was studied by steady-state isotopic transient kinetic analysis coupled to DRIFTS on Ni/SiO2 (Fig. 9) and representative bimetallic (Section S6 in Supplementary Information). Fig. 9 shows the normalized gas phase and FTIR transient responses after the isotopic shift from 13CO2/H2/Ar/He to 12CO2/H2/Ar. These data showed agreement with the CO2 gas phase signal in the IR spectrum (Figure S6.1 and S6.2). The results indicate, now from the perspective of SSITKA-DRIFTS, that there is a consistency between gas phase methane and the intensity of linear and bridge carbonyl species, therefore reaffirming that the later would correspond to a key abundant surface reaction intermediate for methane formation. Furthermore, from a quantitative perspective, this suggests that the residence time of intermediates for methane formation is highly dominated by CO*, indicating that the hydrogenation of this species would correspond to the RDS of methane formation. This is further suggested from the sigmoidal shape of the methane curve that at least 2 pools of intermediates are present for CH4 [33], the main one corresponding to carbonyl species. On the other hand, the consistency between both linear and bridge carbonyl species with methane is also observed, making both suitable candidates as methane intermediates. This is in line with the mechanism proposed in our previous work [16], where methane formation would come from two types of carbonyls, weakly and strongly adsorbed, which are considered to be in equilibrium. Furthermore, previous work [16] confirmed, from fitting of kinetic data with model, that the contribution to the methane formation of the weakly adsorbed carbonyls resulted 1 to 3 orders of magnitude lower than the contribution of the strongly adsorbed carbonyls, allowing the simplification of the kinetics for CH4 formation. The quantitative results obtained from SSITKA-DRIFTS analysis are presented in Table 2 . These values were obtained after extrapolation to zero residence time and correction by the chromatographic effect, as depicted in the literature [33,34]. It is observed that the residence times of intermediates for the formation of both CH4 and CO are higher on the Ni catalyst compared to the NiCo bimetallic sample. The intrinsic turnover frequency (TOFitk) was calculated for bimetallic (0.145 s−1) and Ni (0.042 s−1) catalysts. These TOFitk values indicate that the bimetallic sites are 3.5 times more active than monometallic Ni. At a first glance, this could seem contradictory with the anti-synergistic trend evidenced in Fig. 1. Nevertheless, Table 2 additionally shows that the Ni catalyst display a density of surface intermediates for methane formation (NCH4) 15 times higher than the bimetallic one, in consistency with the higher amount of CObridge-multibound, as observed from the operando-IR measurements and from the intensities evidenced from SSITKA-DRIFTS. Therefore, the results can be rationalized by a higher concentration of less active sites over Ni catalysts. These results, together with the higher activity measured during CO hydrogenation on NiCo as compared with monometallic Ni and Co catalysts, would be indicative of a decrease of available active sites during CO2 hydrogenation on the surface of bimetallic catalyst. In this sense, the lower number of intermediates involved in the methane formation route would be associated with the formation of spectator species, which are produced specifically during CO2 hydrogenation. According to Figs. 6 and 5, it is postulated that this spectator corresponds to formate species. A similar behavior of SSITKA-DRIFTS results was observed for CO formation, where the bimetallic catalyst shows an order of magnitude higher activity (TOFitk) than that observed on monometallic Ni. Also, the density of surface intermediates for CO formation (NCO) resulted significantly lower for the NiCo bimetallic catalyst Table 2). The evident lower density of intermediates for methane and CO formation over the bimetallic catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation may be due to the greater formation of formate species on NiCo surface, which have been shown to be spectators. These spectator species occupy active sites during CO2 hydrogenation, which are not occupied during CO hydrogenation, due to the impossibility of forming formate species during the latter reaction. Other species like carbonate, bicarbonate and hydroxyls can be formed over the catalytic surface during CO2 hydrogenation. Particularly, previous work [16] evidenced that carbonate and bicarbonate IR signals showed a rapid decay when CO2 was removed from the feed, which has been associated with their low stability; therefore, these species would be easily displaced by adsorbed CO*, which dominate the catalytic surface under studied reaction conditions. However, it is not possible to rule out the hydroxyl species as spectator at the catalytic surface. In order to clarify this point, it would be useful to make kinetic measurements by adding water in the feed and study its effect on the product distribution, but this is out of the scope of this work. 3.7 Elementary steps in CO and CO2 hydrogenation and mechanistic origin of the reactant effect on selectivity Scheme 1 shows the sequence of elementary steps, which was previously proposed for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction [16], being also consistent with the measurements shown above. Consequently, the formation of CO(g) and CH4 are described by equation (7) and (8), respectively. The mechanistic route of Scheme 1 considers two types of sites, in one (*) occurs the hydrogen-assisted dissociation of the C-O bond to form CH4, while the other (⊕) participates in the formation of CO through the desorption of weakly adsorbed carbonyl species. (7) r CO = k 5 α P C O 2 0.5 1 + α P C O 2 0.5 (8) r C H 4 = k 7 K H 2 0.5 β P C O 2 0.5 P H 2 0.5 1 + β P C O 2 0.5 2 The terms α and β were defined as α = K 4 k 7 - 0.5 K 3 k 12 K C O 2 0.5 and β = k 7 - 0.5 K 3 k 12 K C O 2 0.5 (derivation in Section S4 in Supporting Information). It is assumed that the CO adsorption–desorption step at low coverages is not at equilibrium, which is consistent with DFT simulations performed at θ CO ∗ = 1 / 16 , θ ∗ = 1 - θ CO ∗ = 15 / 16 , P CO = 1 kPa and T = 200 °C over (111) and (100) Ni, Co and NiCo surfaces (Section S3 in Supporting Information). This would allow obtaining an expression for the direct rates under the studied conditions of CO2 hydrogenation. On the other hand, when the reactions are carried out at higher CO pressures, the coverages would cause the CO adsorption step to equilibrate not allowing a rate expression for CO formation. This has been observed for Ru/SiO2-based catalysts at high surface CO coverages, close to saturation and equilibrium and the reaction is the same that CO hydrogenation and would be shown to be insensitive to the presence of CO2 [15]. It is noteworthy that the rate expression for CH4 formation (Eq. (8) predicts order on PCO2 between −0.5 and 0.5, while measured apparent orders (Fig. 3b) are close to zero, which fall within the range predicted by the model. Also, rate model for CO formation (Eq. (7) predicts order in PCO2 between 0 and 0.5, which is consistent with the apparent order values shown in Fig. 4b. These results confirm the capacity of proposed mechanism and models to properly represent the kinetic data. Moreover, it is also demonstrated that the surface is not fully covered by CO* species at the studied reaction conditions. In fact, Fig. 6a shows that the CO* coverage increases when PCO is increased, which demonstrate that the surface is not totally covered at these conditions. Scheme 2 represents the sequence of elementary steps for the CO hydrogenation reaction. In this case, it is also proposed that the step for by-product CO2 formation is far from equilibrium, due to the low PCO2, which is consistent with the low selectivity toward CO2 observed during CO hydrogenation (Fig. 1). Therefore, the rate expressions for the formation of the products are represented by equation (9) and (10). (9) r C H 4 = k 3 K CO K H 2 0.5 P H 2 0.5 P CO 1 + γ P CO 2 = δ P H 2 0.5 P CO 1 + γ P CO 2 (10) r C O 2 = k 5 K CO P CO ( 1 + χ P H 2 0.5 P CO ) 1 + γ P CO 2 = ε P CO ( 1 + χ P H 2 0.5 P CO ) 1 + γ P CO 2 The term χ = k 11 K H 2 0.5 k 6 K CO represents the effect of O* consumption through the hydrogenation step for hydroxyl formation. In this sense, when the surface is dominated by the carbonyl species, such contribution is not considered, as evidenced under FTS conditions [9,29], but at the methanation conditions of this study it would take relevance and explains the slightly negative reaction order with respect to H2, Fig. 4a. On the other hand, the term γ is associated with Kco if only the carbonyl species is dominant on the surface but may include terms associated with possible limiting step species, i.e., HCO or CHx (derivation is shown in Section S4 of the Supporting information). It is noteworthy that Scheme 2 combines two parallel mechanisms for CO hydrogenation; in the major H-assisted C≡O bond dissociation mechanism, O* is always removed as H2O while in the minor unassisted C≡O bond dissociation, O* can be removed either as CO2 (by CO*) or as H2O (by H*). Therefore, the reaction selectivity during CO hydrogenation is not only determined by the route of O* removal from the surface but also by the type of C≡O bond dissociation mechanism. The very low CO2 formation rate observed on the Ni, Co and NiCo bimetallic catalysts demonstrates that the methane production from hydrogenation of C* formed in the unassisted C≡O bond breaking is a minor pathway on a highly CO*-covered surface. The equations (9) and (10) can be used to rationalize, for example, the similar values (∼60 kJ/mol) observed for CO2 and CH4 activation energies in Fig. 2 on catalysts with higher Co content. According to equations (9) and (10), it is expected that (E3 + 0.5ΔHH2) ≈ E5, which means that E3 > E5 because ΔHH2 < 0. Therefore, the low selectivity toward CO2 observed during CO hydrogenation could be attributed to the lack of vacancy in a CO*-crowded surface. In summary, the Schemes 1 and 2 show a similar mechanism for CH4 formation, varying only the carbon source; the equations (7)–(10) accurately describe the effects of the reactants over a wide range of conditions for both, CH4 and by-product CO and CO2 formation as shown in the parity plots in Fig. 10 . These kinetic data were obtained at conversions lower than 15 % and similar to each other, as shown in Figure S3.3 (Supplementary Material), to avoid effects caused by conversion on kinetic descriptors, as discussed above. Consequently, we assumed a differential reactor to fit the kinetic data and obtain the proposed model for CO, CO2 and CH4 formation (Eqs. (7)–(10). Nonetheless, in order support our assumption of differential reactor, the kinetic parameters were also estimated by fitting the data from one of the bimetallic catalysts to a PFR model (integral reactor), which imply the simultaneous solution of the two differential equations with the kinetics proposed for CO2 hydrogenation. As shown in Table S5.1 and Figure S5.3 (Supplementary Material), the kinetic parameters obtained from regression with PFR model resulted very similar to those estimated from the differential model, therefore, supporting the assumption of differential reactor analysis of the data obtained at the reaction conditions used in this study. Fig. 11 a shows the parameters adjusted at 280 °C from the regression of kinetic data with equations (9) and (10) for mono and bimetallic catalysts for CO hydrogenation. It can be observed that the lumped parameter (δ = k3 KCOKH2 0.5) associated with the RDS for methane formation is higher as the Co content increases, which indicates that the intrinsic activity of sites for CH4 formation increases with Co content in the catalysts. This behavior is consistent with TOFCH4 shown in Fig. 1a during CO hydrogenation and also agrees with that obtained in the SSITKA-DRIFTS measurements for CO2 hydrogenation (with similar route for CH4 formation), where the sites associated with CH4 formation on the NiCo bimetallic catalysts are more reactive, but less abundant, than on Ni. These results suggest that the cause of the differences in catalytic performance between CO and CO2 hydrogenation is related to the density of intermediates involved in the methane formation pathway. The number of those intermediates is affected by the co-concentrations of spectators or CO*-displacing species, which are proposed to be formates during CO2 hydrogenation. In this sense, if we assume that the only dominant term at the surface during both hydrogenations is the CO* species, it is possible to compare the parameters associated with the hydrogenation step derived from the regression of equations (8) and (9) for both reactions (CO2 and CO hydrogenations), Fig. 11b. The trend shown by these parameters with Co content is similar to that of CH4 formation activity presented by the catalysts in Fig. 1a. It should be note that the parameters consider the changes in the fraction of active sites. This supports the idea of a lower density of sites involved in methane formation during CO2 hydrogenation, in agreement with the evidence presented in the spectroscopic and isotopic analysis, where formate species are spectators, i.e., they occupy part of the catalyst surface without a contribution in CH4 formation. On the other hand, during CO hydrogenation it is not possible to form such formate species, showing an increase in the value of the hydrogenation parameter with the cobalt content, with weaker effect for Co content higher than 0.5, evidencing the electronic similarities between the bimetallic catalysts and Co, which also was demonstrated by DFT (Section S2 in Supporting Information). On the other hand, the parameters ε and χ for bimetallic catalysts, Fig. 11a, associated with the formation of CO2 during CO hydrogenation and with the fraction of O* that allows the formation of OH* and subsequent H2O, respectively, show a negative shift with respect to their average-weighted value. This suggests that monometallic surfaces are more active than bimetallic surfaces for O* formation through direct dissociation (step 6), but also show higher O* rejection activity through H2O formation (step 11). 4 Conclusions This study provides kinetic, operando-spectroscopic and isotopic results which demonstrate the similarity between the reaction mechanisms of CO and CO2 hydrogenation on SiO2-supported Ni, Co and bimetallic NiCo catalysts. It was shown that the CO2 methanation pathway proceeds via CO formation and its subsequential hydrogenation instead of parallel product formation routes. Moreover, kinetic and isotopic results as well as theoretical calculations demonstrate that methane formation mechanisms from CO and CO2 share the same rate-limiting step, specifically the H-assisted dissociation of the carbonyl formed by CO adsorption or direct CO2 dissociation, respectively. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the formation of the undesired products proceeds via routes that do not involve hydrogen, being formed by desorption of the carbonyl species on weak sites (from CO2) or through a direct CO dissociation step that allows the rejection of O* forming CO2 (from CO). Even though the methane formation proceeds through identical pathways regardless the carbon source, it was observed different effect of catalyst composition on CH4 formation turnover rate, namely a slightly synergistic effect during CO hydrogenation and markedly anti-synergistic effect during CO2 hydrogenation. This behavior is explained by the formation of spectator species (HCOO*) occupying catalyst surface during CO2 hydrogenation on the bimetallic catalysts, while these formate species are not formed during CO hydrogenation. SSITKA results suggest that the bimetallic NiCo sites involved in the route for CH4 formation from CO2 are more reactive, but less abundant than in the monometallic catalysts. This work contributes to the deeper comprehension of the relationship between CO and CO2 hydrogenation and, consequently, to the rational design of new materials with better catalytic performance for COx methanation process. coredata.dc:description: Although CO and CO2 hydrogenation reactions have been extensively studied, there is still significant controversy regarding the mechanism of methane formation and the routes for byproducts, especially when both carbon sources are simultaneously present. This work combines kinetic, operando-spectroscopic, isotopic techniques and DFT calculations to elucidate the relationships between CO and CO2 hydrogenation over mono Ni, Co and bimetallic NiCo catalysts with similar metal dispersion. The bimetallic catalysts showed a slight synergistic effect for methane formation from CO, while from CO2 the effect was opposite, showing a negative shift of activity as compared with those observed on the monometallic catalysts. The kinetic analysis shows similar apparent order with respect to H2 (∼0.5) and an inverse secondary isotope kinetic effect (<1) for both methanation reactions, suggesting that CH4 formation proceeds via C-O bond breaking in an H*-assisted mechanism, where the rate-determining step was not shown to be sensitive to the carbon source. The anti-synergistic effect observed on the bimetallic catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation is explained by the formation of unreactive HCOO* species (spectator), which generate a lower density of methane intermediates. On the other hand, the formation of the undesired products, i.e., CO or CO2 during CO2 or CO hydrogenation, respectively, shows relevant differences since the CO formation during CO2 hydrogenation proceeds through the desorption of the carbonyl species adsorbed on weak sites, meanwhile the CO2 formation from CO hydrogenation is due to a minority route of direct dissociation of CO, allowing the rejection of O* with CO* to produce CO2. This study contributes to elucidate the routes that determine the selectivity and reactivity for CO and CO2 hydrogenation and their mechanistic relationship. This information is valuable for the rational design and development of new materials with high performance during hydrogenation processes.
